(41) 81stConclusions,Minute 1.)6. The Minister without Portfolio reminded the War cabinet of the position in this matter. The United States Government didnot intend to ask for payment for articles passing to us under the lease-Lend Procedure. They proposed, however, that Article VIIof the proposed Lease-Lend Agreement should provide that theterms and conditions upon which this country received Lease-Lendaid from the United States of America should include provision foragreed action to promote advantageous economic relations betweenthe two countries and for the betterment of world-wide economic relations. The United States Grovernment wished the form of wordsused in this respect to include a provision against discriminatorytreatment in international commerce and had made it clear that bythat phrase they intended that we should commit ourselves to the eventual abolition of Imperial Preference.This matter had, of course, been touched on in Article IV ofthe Atlantic Charter. The words there used had, however, beensafeguarded by " due respect for .... existing obligations."The revised draft of Article VII of the proposed Lease-LendAgreement handed to our Ambassador at Washington on the2nd December referred to '' the elimination of all forms of discrimination -natory treatment in international commerce'' and to '' thereduction of tariffs and other trade barriers.'"'This matter had been discussed on the 23rd December at ameeting of the Committee on Economic Aspects of EeconstructionProblems.* The Committee had also had before them certaintelegrams explaining in some detail the interpretation which theUnited States authorities placed on the revised draft ofArticle VII. At this meeting Ministers had agreed that a telegram should be sent to our Ambassador in Washington to the effect that difficulties were seen in accepting the revised draft of Article VII;but that the case might be different if an agreed interpretation ofthe article could be arrived at which could be made public if theneed arose. It had been suggested that our Ambassador should discuss with the Prime Minister the practicability of securing suchan agreed interpretation.A further telegram had now been received from Washington(No. 6105 of the 29th December, 1941) indicating that the PrimeMinister had not been able to deal with the matter, owing to the pressure of other business. This telegram also reported thatMr. Hull had asked when we should be able to reply, since he wouldbe obliged to make a statement on the matter before Congress not later than mid-January, when it was proposed to ask Congress to vote further Lease-Lend appropriations.The Minister without Portfolio said that a further meeting ofMinisters had been held at short notice on the previous night. after some discussion, it had been decided to telegraph to the Ambassador,for his private information, that after careful discussion herebetween Ministers it was felt that this matter, on which divergentviews were held, must await the Prime Ministers return beforefurther instructions could be sent to him (Lord Halifax).The War Cabinet-Agreed that a telegram should be despatched on these lines.Great George Street, S.W. 1,January 1, 1942.E.R.P.
